page.title: 03St.Botolphs Church Swyncombe
page.content: The church is a Norman Pilgrim Church dedicated to St. Botolph, the English Patron Saint of travellers. It was com- pleted in 1020 and remains virtually unchanged today. It is built from flint stone laid in a herringbone pattern. On the South wall is the oldest double aumbry in England that is still in use. The 14th. century bell is preserved in- side the building. There is 17th. and 18th. century stained glass with armor- ial bearings remounted on modern glass. Work in 1850 restored the original wall paintings. The original solid stone arch with lefthand squint was replaced in 1910 by a pine screen. This was being changed in 1914 when the work had to stop due to the internment of the donors. Consequently the necessary figures are missing. The original rel- iquary was uncovered in 1982.
